nodes.name: Interactive LLM Agent

fields.name: customPrompt
fields.value:
You are given transaction anomaly detection results from an Isolation Forest model.
Column: `isolated_prediction` (value less than 6 = anomaly,  equal or more than 6 = good).  


Your tasks are:  
1. Identify **each anomaly line item** (isolated_prediction < 6) and strictly ignore good transactions which are (isolated_prediction > 6).  
2. For every anomaly, show the **Invoice ID** and **Vendor ID**.  
3. For each anomaly, provide a **short Root Cause Analysis (RCA)** (e.g., duplicate invoice, odd hours, abnormal amount, quantity mismatch, rate discrepancy, missing approvals, suspicious vendor concentration, inflated logged hours, unusual frequency, new/unknown vendor, round-number fraud, weekend/holiday invoice, receipt missing, vendor-item anomaly).  
4. Provide **one short actionable insight** per anomaly (e.g., enable duplicate check, restrict off-hour invoices, set approval workflow, cross-verify bank accounts, enforce receipt validation, tighten contract controls, monitor vendor frequency, audit round amounts, segregate new vendors, cap hours vs logged, SKU-level monitoring).
5. Keep the tone concise, business-oriented, and easy to read.  

### Strictly go through the whole data line by line and add the above for each row where 'Anomaly' value is 'True'. Please use all the examples given in 3rd and 4th point effectively.


### Output Format:
Return a valid JSON object with a single key `"items"` containing an array of objects.  For rca and actionable_insights select short, relevant values from the examples provided in points 3 and 4 (e.g., duplicate invoice, odd hours, abnormal amount, quantity mismatch, rate discrepancy, missing approvals, suspicious vendor concentration, inflated logged hours, unusual frequency, new/unknown vendor, round-number fraud, weekend/holiday invoice, receipt missing, vendor-item anomaly; and actionable insights like enable duplicate check, restrict off-hour invoices, set approval workflow, cross-verify bank accounts, enforce receipt validation, tighten contract controls, monitor vendor frequency, audit round amounts, segregate new vendors, cap hours vs logged, SKU-level monitoring). Do not hardcode only the sample shown below.

### JSON Structure (example for reference):
```json
{
  "items": [
    {
      "invoice_id": "INV1590",
      "vendor_id": "V1014",
      "rca": "Duplicate invoice detected",
      "actionable_insight": "Enable duplicate check"
    },
    {
      "invoice_id": "INV1590",
      "vendor_id": "V1014",
      "rca": "Odd-hour submission",
      "actionable_insight": "Restrict off-hour invoices"
    },
    {
      "invoice_id": "INV1590",
      "vendor_id": "V1014",
      "rca": "Abnormal invoice amount",
      "actionable_insight": "Flag outlier amounts"
    }
  ]
}

fields.name: customPrompt
fields.value:
You are given transaction anomaly detection results from an Isolation Forest model.   Column: `isolated_prediction` (value less than 6 = anomaly,  equal or more than 6 = good).   Your tasks are:   1. Identify the **top 5 vendors** with the **highest number of anomalies** (isolated_prediction < 6) and strictly ignore good transactions which are (isolated_prediction > 6).   2. For each vendor, perform a **Root Cause Analysis (RCA)** highlighting key reasons (e.g., duplicate invoices, odd hours, abnormal amounts, contract deviations).   3. Provide **3 actionable insights** per vendor on how to reduce anomalies or improve fraud prevention.   4. Present the output in a **neat, structured HTML table** with:      - Vendor ID in **bold blue text**.      - RCA column in **red text**.      - Actionable Insights column in **green text with bullet points**.      - Table styled with borders and alternating row colors.   5. Add one **Overall Recommendation** row at the bottom summarizing common mitigation strategies across all vendors.   6. Keep the tone concise, business-oriented, and suitable for risk & compliance teams.   Make sure to return **only the HTML table output** so it can be directly rendered in the app.   Use the following example as a reference for structure, formatting, and colors: ```html                                                                                                                                                                                  
Vendor IDRoot Cause Analysis (RCA)Actionable Insights
VENDOR_102High anomaly count due to repeated duplicate invoices with identical amounts submitted on the same date.        
             
  • Enable duplicate invoice checks before approval.
    •          
  • Set vendor-level spending thresholds with automated alerts.
    •          
  • Mandate secondary approval for invoices over 50K.
    •        
     
VENDOR_208Anomalies linked to invoices raised outside business hours (2–4 AM) and irregular unit pricing.        
             
  • Restrict invoice submission to business hours.
    •          
  • Introduce unit-price validation rules against contract.
    •          
  • Investigate vendor system access logs for off-hour activity.
    •        
     
VENDOR_310Outlier invoice amounts significantly higher than peer vendors for similar services.        
             
  • Benchmark vendor pricing against industry averages.
    •          
  • Route invoices >2x median price for manual review.
    •          
  • Negotiate revised contract terms.
    •        
     
VENDOR_415Frequent anomalies due to missing approval details and inconsistent customer IDs.        
             
  • Mandate complete metadata before invoice submission.
    •          
  • Audit internal mapping of customer IDs to vendor submissions.
    •          
  • Automate approval workflow integration.
    •        
     
VENDOR_509Suspicious clustering of invoices just below approval thresholds (9,900 when 10,000 requires extra approval).        
             
  • Introduce random checks for invoices near threshold values.
    •          
  • Change approval policy to cumulative vendor spend instead of per-invoice.
    •          
  • Escalate to compliance for further investigation.
    •        
     
        Overall Recommendation: Strengthen duplicate checks, enforce threshold-based approvals, and introduce anomaly alerts in real-time monitoring.
